name: Delta Airlines
title: January's imprint on aviation: founding flights, industry firsts and early trailblazers | CAPA
description:
The first week of January marks the start of the new year.
The start of the year has also witnessed a number of historic 'firsts' in aviation.
The first week of January has considerable significance for aviation companies, ranging from Avro Aircraft to Lufthansa and LOT Polish.
It has also marked milestones in the lives of a number of aviation trailblazers from the early decades of powered flight and the introduction of the first airline uniforms.
During a century of monumental change Qantas has provided global aviation industry leadership in product innovation, technical excellence, operational performance and managerial acumen.
text:
The first week of January marks the start of the new year. The start of the year has also witnessed a number of historic 'firsts' in aviation.

As long ago as 3-Jan-1496, for example, Leonardo da Vinci tested a flying machine. It failed.

More successful was the world's first commercial airline service, launched on 1-Jan-1914.

The first week of January has considerable significance for aviation companies, ranging from Avro Aircraft to Lufthansa and LOT Polish.

It has also marked milestones in the lives of a number of aviation trailblazers from the early decades of powered flight and the introduction of the first airline uniforms.

On 16-Nov-2020 Qantas turned 100.

During a century of monumental change Qantas has provided global aviation industry leadership in product innovation, technical excellence, operational performance and managerial acumen.

In doing so it has survived many dark moments. Periodically reinventing itself, it is a rare exemplar of a successful and resilient Australian business with global reach. Today it is confident in both its capability and in its economic and social relevance: and another reinvention is in prospect.

name: Nvidia
title: Circling the Nvidia moat - Tech Brew
description:
TL;DR: Meta’s new partnership with Google to use more of its AI chips is another sign that companies want to be less dependent on Nvidia—but Nvidia will still be king for the foreseeable future.
Meanwhile, gaming GPU prices could get even more expensive.
What happened: If it’s a day ending in y, chances are major AI companies are making deals.
Amazon may inject up to $10 billion into OpenAI, an investment that would see the ChatGPT-maker use more of Amazon’s AI chips.
New reports suggest Nvidia could be cutting up to 40% of gaming GPU production in 2026.
text:
TL;DR: Meta’s new partnership with Google to use more of its AI chips is another sign that companies want to be less dependent on Nvidia—but Nvidia will still be king for the foreseeable future. Meanwhile, gaming GPU prices could get even more expensive.

What happened: If it’s a day ending in y, chances are major AI companies are making deals. This week alone, there are reports that:

Google and Meta are teaming up to make Google’s in-house AI chips play nicer with the leading AI development framework, which was originally developed at Meta.

Meta is in talks to spend billions on Google’s chips, generally much cheaper than Nvidia’s, starting in 2027.

Amazon may inject up to $10 billion into OpenAI, an investment that would see the ChatGPT-maker use more of Amazon’s AI chips.

These new partnerships show just how much key AI players want alternatives to Nvidia, even as they continue to strike deals with the GPU giant.

Why it matters: Right now, Nvidia is the go-to chip provider in AI computing, partly because it’s easiest to use. Its programming layer and developer tools platform, which makes AI code run efficiently on Nvidia GPUs, is the industry standard. It doesn’t mean the software is irreplaceable, but first-mover advantage has a hell of a gravitational pull: One widely cited estimate put Nvidia at having 85% of the global AI chip market as of mid-2025. That market dominance has given Nvidia a lot of control over pricing and the terms of the deals it strikes. If one company can set the going rate for the most in-demand hardware, everyone else ends up paying a premium until real substitutes exist at scale.

What does this mean for you?: For consumers, Nvidia’s primacy in the AI fervor doesn’t bode well for gaming GPU prices, which have already been sky-high for years now. New reports suggest Nvidia could be cutting up to 40% of gaming GPU production in 2026.

Is dethroning Nvidia realistic?: No one is snatching the crown from a $4 trillion-dollar company tomorrow. More realistically, what we might see in the next few years is a slow erosion of Nvidia’s power. If alternative chips become easy to use with mainstream AI tools, Nvidia’s share could slide from “total domination” to just “enormous.” —WK

name: H&M
title: Black cabs backed with fairer tax system - GOV.UK
description:
Cabbies and small taxi companies to benefit as online minicab firms stopped from using niche scheme to avoid paying tax.
This means that black cabs will no longer have to compete with online mini cab firms who are misusing this scheme to pay less VAT.
Chancellor of the Exchequer, Rachel Reeves, said: We’re putting the brakes on the illegitimate use of a niche tax scheme to protect everyday cabbies.
For too long, drivers and small operators paying the full 20% VAT have had to compete with online mini cab firms benefiting from a niche tax scheme.
Smaller operators outside London, where passengers book directly with drivers, and all black cabs will not be affected by this reform to the Tour Operator’s Margin Scheme.
text:
Cabbies and small taxi companies to benefit as online minicab firms stopped from using niche scheme to avoid paying tax.

Reform announced at Budget ensures everyday cabbies can compete fairly.

Closure to bring in £700 million a year to help cut waiting lists, cut debt and borrowing, and cut the cost of living.

As announced at the Budget by the Chancellor, private hire vehicle operators in London will no longer be able to use the Tour Operators Margin Scheme - a niche tax scheme designed for tour operators and holiday coach trips – to significantly reduce the VAT they pay on fares.

This means that black cabs will no longer have to compete with online mini cab firms who are misusing this scheme to pay less VAT.

Chancellor of the Exchequer, Rachel Reeves, said:

We’re putting the brakes on the illegitimate use of a niche tax scheme to protect everyday cabbies. We’ll use the £700m a year this raises to deliver the country’s priorities - cutting the cost of living, cutting waiting lists and cutting debt and borrowing.

Steve McNamara, General Secretary of the Licensed Taxi Drivers Association, said:

The government’s decision to apply VAT to all private hire journeys is a landmark step for fairness and integrity in our industry. For too long, drivers and small operators paying the full 20% VAT have had to compete with online mini cab firms benefiting from a niche tax scheme.

We welcome this move and commend the government for taking decisive action.

The Tour Operator’s Margin Scheme is a specialist VAT rule designed for genuine travel and holiday businesses, allowing them to pay VAT only on the profit they make on package trips, not the full fare, typically reducing the effective VAT rate to 4%.

First announced by the Chancellor at Budget 2025, today’s measure will prevent the small number of big companies accessing the Tour Operator’s Margin Scheme, as they have been doing.

By supporting fairer competition, the government is protecting around £700 million in revenue, helping deliver the public’s priorities - cutting waiting lists, cutting debt and borrowing, and cutting the cost of living.

Smaller operators outside London, where passengers book directly with drivers, and all black cabs will not be affected by this reform to the Tour Operator’s Margin Scheme.

title: Celltrion completes acquisition of U.S. biopharmaceutical plant | Yonhap News Agency
description:
SEOUL, Jan. 2 (Yonhap) -- Celltrion Inc., a major South Korean biopharmaceutical company, has completed the acquisition of a biopharmaceutical manufacturing plant in the United States, the company said Friday, paving the way for local contract manufacturing deals under tariff-free conditions.
Celltrion USA Inc., the company's U.S. unit, finalized the deal to acquire the 460 billion-won (US$317 million) facility in New Jersey from U.S. drugmaker Eli Lilly, the company said in a press release.
Following the acquisition, Celltrion has signed a contract manufacturing organization (CMO) agreement worth 678.7 billion won to produce biopharmaceutical products for Eli Lilly for three years through 2029, it added.
"The U.S. acquisition was aimed at proactively responding to rapidly changing biopharmaceutical markets.
Celltrion has been expanding its global biosimilar portfolio, increasing the number of approved products from six to 11.
text:
SEOUL, Jan. 2 (Yonhap) -- Celltrion Inc., a major South Korean biopharmaceutical company, has completed the acquisition of a biopharmaceutical manufacturing plant in the United States, the company said Friday, paving the way for local contract manufacturing deals under tariff-free conditions.

Celltrion USA Inc., the company's U.S. unit, finalized the deal to acquire the 460 billion-won (US$317 million) facility in New Jersey from U.S. drugmaker Eli Lilly, the company said in a press release.

Following the acquisition, Celltrion has signed a contract manufacturing organization (CMO) agreement worth 678.7 billion won to produce biopharmaceutical products for Eli Lilly for three years through 2029, it added.

"The U.S. acquisition was aimed at proactively responding to rapidly changing biopharmaceutical markets. The company plans to expand the facility to secure additional global CMO contracts," a company official said.

On Wednesday, Celltrion projected its annual operating profit would exceed 1 trillion won for the first time this year, driven by strong sales of high-margin biosimilar products.

Celltrion has been expanding its global biosimilar portfolio, increasing the number of approved products from six to 11. The company aims to commercialize 18 biosimilars by 2030 and 41 by 2038.

Its only original drug, Zymfentra, is currently sold in the U.S. to treat autoimmune diseases. The product is marketed as Remsima SC in Europe and other regions.

name: S&P Global
title: North of 60 Mining News' 2025 Top Ten
description:
Over the course of 2025, North of 60 Mining News published more than 560 articles that provided in-depth coverage of the projects, policies, and people shaping the mining industry across Alaska and northern Canada.
From securing sites for antimony refineries and tracking gold price outlooks to revisiting legal battles and responding to underground emergencies, here is a countdown of the 10 most-read North of 60 Mining News articles of 2025.
10 – Greenland caught in resource power struggle The tenth most popular North of 60 Mining News article of 2025 examined the competing interests shaping mineral development in Greenland and the broader implications for Arctic resource governance.
9 on the North of 60 Mining New 2025 Top Ten, this article provided insights into the newly confirmed U.S. Geological Survey Director Ned Mamula's call for renewed investment in domestic mining to strengthen supply chains and economic resilience.
6 – Alaska mining is achieving critical mass The sixth most-read North of 60 Mining News article of 2025 explored how Alaska's mining sector is approaching a pivotal moment when soaring metals prices, favorable federal policies, and the potential development of world-class mining projects have converged.
text:
From critical mineral supply chains and courtroom battles to market signals and safety incidents, these are the most-read articles.

Over the course of 2025, North of 60 Mining News published more than 560 articles that provided in-depth coverage of the projects, policies, and people shaping the mining industry across Alaska and northern Canada. As global demand for minerals intensified and supply chain pressures mounted, readers consistently sought reporting that connected broader market and policy developments to the projects and people shaping the mining industry across Alaska and northern Canada.

Readers closely followed progress on critical mineral projects, shifts in permitting and mining policy, major corporate moves, and the market forces influencing exploration and mine development. Just as closely watched were stories highlighting the human side of mining.

From securing sites for antimony refineries and tracking gold price outlooks to revisiting legal battles and responding to underground emergencies, here is a countdown of the 10 most-read North of 60 Mining News articles of 2025.

No. 10 – Greenland caught in resource power struggle

The tenth most popular North of 60 Mining News article of 2025 examined the competing interests shaping mineral development in Greenland and the broader implications for Arctic resource governance.

As global demand for rare earths and other critical minerals accelerates, Greenland has emerged as a focal point for governments and companies seeking secure, non-Chinese supply sources. The article examined how these pressures intersect with local debates over environmental protection, Indigenous rights, and political autonomy, highlighting the complexity of resource development in the Arctic.

For readers who have long followed North of 60 Mining News' coverage of Alaska and northern Canada, the Greenland story offered a case study in how northern jurisdictions are grappling with challenges and opportunities of supplying the minerals needed for modern economies while retaining local control over resource decisions – an increasingly familiar challenge across the North.

No. 9 – USGS director champions domestic mining

Landing at No. 9 on the North of 60 Mining New 2025 Top Ten, this article provided insights into the newly confirmed U.S. Geological Survey Director Ned Mamula's call for renewed investment in domestic mining to strengthen supply chains and economic resilience.

The story highlighted the importance of geological mapping, resource assessments, and science-based decision-making in promoting responsible mining. Alaska featured prominently as a jurisdiction where strong mineral potential, paired with robust geoscience data, could help reduce reliance on foreign supplies.

North of 60 Mining News readers responded to the article's practical focus on how better information and clearer policy signals can translate into real project advancement –particularly in America's Last Frontier state, where geology and logistics play an outsized role in development decisions.

No. 8 – Anglo, Teck to merge into $53B copper giant

The No. 8 most-read article of 2025 covered the pending merger of Anglo American and Teck Resources, a deal set to create a $53 billion critical minerals-focused mining company.

The story examined how this consolidation among major producers reflects long-term demand expectations for copper tied to electrification, infrastructure, and energy transition technologies. It also considered what the merger could mean for project prioritization and investment strategies in northern mining jurisdictions.

For mining companies, investors, policymakers, and stakeholders across the North, the Anglo Teck article connected a major mining merger to potential downstream impacts on exploration funding, development timelines, and competition for capital allocations for projects across Alaska and northern Canada.

No. 7 – Skibinski presses for mining policies in DC

The seventh most-read article provided insights into Alaska Miners Association Executive Director Deantha Skibinski's Washington, D.C., advocacy for policies supporting responsible domestic mining.

The story detailed discussions around permitting reform, infrastructure investment, and regulatory clarity – issues that directly affect whether mining projects in Alaska deliver the minerals critical to America's economy and national security, or stall. It provided readers with a clear look at how industry voices are engaging federal policymakers to address long-standing development barriers at a time when Alaska is increasingly viewed as a strategic resource to the U.S.

The article serves as a reminder that decisions made thousands of miles away can have immediate and long-term consequences for mining projects and economies across the North.

No. 6 – Alaska mining is achieving critical mass

The sixth most-read North of 60 Mining News article of 2025 explored how Alaska's mining sector is approaching a pivotal moment when soaring metals prices, favorable federal policies, and the potential development of world-class mining projects have converged.

While Alaska's mining industry has been building toward critical mass for decades, the 2024 election started a chain reaction that could sustain sector growth over the coming decade.

The significance of Alaska's mineral wealth and strategic Arctic location is now a headlining topic of national conversation – from the Pentagon to the White House and Capitol Hill.

"Strategically, Alaska is one of the most important states for our nation, with its location, minerals, land, and natural resource assets," Congressman Pete Stauber (R-Minn.) said during an August tour of Alaska.

The article captured a growing sense that Alaska's mining future is increasingly defined not only by its world-renowned geology, but also by an increasing recognition of the Far North State's enormous capacity to deliver a domestic supply of minerals and metals critical to America's economic well-being and national security.

No. 5 – S&P Global forecasts strong gold prices

Landing at No. 5, this article reported on S&P Global's forecast for continued strength in gold prices and what that could mean for mineral exploration and mining across the North.

Gold remains a cornerstone of mining in Alaska and northern Canada, and the outlook reinforced the precious metal's role in supporting exploration, mine expansions, and new development.

At the time this article was published, gold mining companies and their investors were celebrating the potential that the precious metal would break through the $3,000/oz barrier. Over the following 10 months, the price of gold has continued to climb more than 50% to fresh new highs above $4,500/oz.

The record gold prices heading into 2026 exceed S&P Global's most bullish predictions at the beginning of 2025. While the global financial analyst foresees a pullback in prices, even the steepest retreat is expected to land higher than record highs set just 18 months ago.

The S&P Global gold forecast story provided mining companies with gold mines and projects across Alaska and Canada's North with a reason to celebrate going into 2025. The steep and steady climb throughout the year, however, far exceeded what was viewed as a bullish forecast when the article was published.

No. 4 – Red Chris mine workers trapped underground

The fourth most-read article of 2025 covered a pair of underground mine collapses that trapped three workers at the Red Chris copper-gold mine in British Columbia's Golden Triangle.

The story provided a first glimpse into the underground mine emergency as the events were unfolding, and set the stage for articles that provided readers with updates as Newmont, the provincial government, and the wider mining sector deployed the latest technologies to quickly rescue the three trapped miners, without putting other workers in harm's way.

The story underscored the importance of preparedness, communication, and emergency response systems.

Its high readership reflected the mining community's deep concern for the safety of the underground miners at Red Chris, and a solidarity across operations, jurisdictions, and companies when incidents occur.

No. 3 – Alaska revives U.S. antimony supply chain

Coming in at No. 3 on North of 60 Mining News' 2025 Top Ten is an article that detailed Alaska's growing role in reviving a domestic antimony supply chain after decades of U.S. dependence on foreign sources.

The article highlighted how the emerging deposits of high-grade antimony at Alaska mine projects could help restore a secure, domestic supply of this metalloid critical to defense, manufacturing, and energy applications.

Readers were drawn to a potential link between high-grade antimony mineralization on the outskirts of Fairbanks, Alaska, U.S. Antimony's smelter in Montana, and a $245 U.S. Defense Logistics Agency contract to deliver antimony bars into the nation's strategic stockpile.

The article reinforced Alaska's importance in addressing U.S. critical mineral supply vulnerabilities while creating new economic opportunities in the state.

No. 2 – Pebble back in court over EPA veto

The second-most-read article of 2025 reported on renewed legal challenges surrounding the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's veto of the proposed Pebble mine.

The long-running dispute over the development of a mine at the world-class Pebble copper-gold-silver-molybdenum-rhenium deposit in Southwest Alaska remains one of the U.S.'s most closely watched mining cases, and readers closely followed its return to the courtroom. The article examined what the latest legal developments surrounding the Pebble case could mean for permitting certainty and federal authority over large mining projects in Alaska and across the nation.

Its strong readership reflected Pebble's world-class critical minerals potential and the enduring influence the project has on perceptions of regulatory risk, investment climate, and the future of large-scale mining in Alaska.

No. 1 – Alaska antimony refinery site secured

Coming in at No. 1 on North of 60 Mining News' Top Ten articles of 2025 is a story that provided readers with unprecedented insights into Nova Minerals' securing of a site for an antimony refinery at Port MacKenzie near Anchorage, Alaska.

The milestone marked a concrete step toward adding downstream critical mineral processing capacity in America's Last Frontier state, moving beyond extraction and closer to a fully integrated supply chain. Readers responded to the project's implications for job creation, economic diversification, and Alaska's growing position as a key supplier of domestic critical minerals.

Its top ranking reflected strong interest in developments that translate Alaska's resources into operating facilities with lasting implications for the state's economy and the nation's mineral security.

name: Eli Lilly
title: Should You Buy Pfizer While It's Under $30? | The Motley Fool
description:
Trading at a bit under $25 apiece, Pfizer's (PFE 0.36%) shares appear tentatively cheap.
Is Pfizer worth investing in at current levels?
Further, Pfizer has doubled down on acquisitions, which has helped it improve its pipeline.
Pfizer should launch several new products that will bolster its lineup through the end of the decade.
First, Pfizer penned a deal with the Trump administration that will allow it to avoid tariffs for three years.
text:
Trading at a bit under $25 apiece, Pfizer's (PFE 0.36%) shares appear tentatively cheap. However, the pharmaceutical giant reached these levels because it has faced significant headwinds, resulting in a poor stock market performance over the past three years.

Yet, what is the outlook for the struggling giant from here? Is Pfizer worth investing in at current levels?

Slowly engineering a comeback

Pfizer's revenue and earnings have been inconsistent over the past few years. To make matters worse, the drugmaker will encounter important patent cliffs within a few years, including that of Eliquis, an anticoagulant and one of its best-selling drugs. Even so, the company has been gradually earning new approvals, some of which should have a meaningful impact on its financial results as label expansions are secured.

Further, Pfizer has doubled down on acquisitions, which has helped it improve its pipeline. The company now has a comprehensive list of candidates across multiple therapeutic areas, with a particular focus on cancer. It also boasts a promising candidate for weight loss. Pfizer should launch several new products that will bolster its lineup through the end of the decade.

Even more reasons to buy

Purchasing shares of top companies when they are down is a great way to earn excellent returns over the long run. Pfizer is a top pick to consider, given that it has been making the right moves to overcome slow (or non-existent) revenue growth and patent cliffs. And there are even more reasons to consider the stock. Here are three.

First, Pfizer penned a deal with the Trump administration that will allow it to avoid tariffs for three years. Second, the company is a solid dividend payer. It has increased its payouts by 51.3% over the past decade, and boasts a juicy forward yield of 6.9%.

name: L’Oréal
title: Ética en la IA: El Dilema de los RRHH en la Era de los Algoritmos - Prevención Integral
description:
La paradoja es clara: la IA promete eficiencia, pero sin ética, se convierte en un riesgo reputacional y legal.
La solución llegó con estándares como el IEEE CertifAIEd, que desde 2025 certifica algoritmos libres de sesgos.
Empresas como L’Oréal y Nestlé ya exigen este sello a sus proveedores de tecnología de RRHH.
Y en IBM, los algoritmos de desarrollo de talento se entrenan con datos anónimos de 50 países para garantizar diversidad cultural.
La respuesta está en la colaboración: en Accenture, los gerentes reciben alertas de IA cuando un algoritmo sugiere una acción riesgosa (ej.
text:
En 2025, una empresa europea de logística enfrentó una demanda millonaria: su sistema de IA para promociones había excluido sistemáticamente a empleados mayores de 50 años, priorizando perfiles “jóvenes y adaptables”. El caso, reportado por The Financial Times, destapó una verdad incómoda: mientras el 89% de las empresas usan inteligencia artificial (IA) en gestión del talento, solo el 34% audita sus algoritmos para evitar discriminación, según Deloitte (2025). La paradoja es clara: la IA promete eficiencia, pero sin ética, se convierte en un riesgo reputacional y legal.

El reclutamiento es el campo minado. Herramientas como HireVue o Pymetrics analizan tonos de voz, palabras clave en CVs o respuestas en juegos cognitivos. Pero en 2024, un estudio de MIT reveló que el 42% de estos sistemas penalizaban a candidatos con discapacidades auditivas al evaluar “capacidad de comunicación”. La solución llegó con estándares como el IEEE CertifAIEd, que desde 2025 certifica algoritmos libres de sesgos. Empresas como L’Oréal y Nestlé ya exigen este sello a sus proveedores de tecnología de RRHH.

La transparencia es otro desafío. Según Gartner (2025), el 68% de los empleados desconfía de cómo se usan sus datos en decisiones de promoción o despidos. Plataformas como Workday responden con “explicabilidad algorítmica”: al finalizar una evaluación, el sistema muestra qué factores (desempeño, habilidades blandas, etc.) influyeron en el resultado. “Antes, los trabajadores se sentían juzgados por una caja negra. Ahora, la IA es un espejo con instrucciones”, explica Clara Ríos, directora de Recursos Humanos en BBVA México.

La privacidad también está en juego. En 2025, la UE amplió el GDPR para incluir “datos emocionales” (estrés, engagement) recolectados por herramientas como Microsoft Viva o Peakon. Las multas por mal uso pueden alcanzar el 4% de la facturación global. Por eso, gigantes como SAP han creado comités internos donde empleados revisan qué datos se recopilan y cómo se procesan.

Pero no todo es regulación. Algunas empresas convierten la ética en ventaja competitiva. Salesforce, por ejemplo, lanzó en 2024 su Ethical AI Toolkit, que permite a los equipos de RRHH simular escenarios de contratación para detectar sesgos. Y en IBM, los algoritmos de desarrollo de talento se entrenan con datos anónimos de 50 países para garantizar diversidad cultural. Los resultados son tangibles: según Forbes (2025), estas compañías tienen un 40% más de candidatos diversos en procesos de selección.

El futuro del trabajo exige un equilibrio delicado. Mientras el 76% de los CEO presionan por más automatización en RRHH (IDC, 2025), el 61% de los empleados exigen controles humanos en decisiones críticas (Gallup, 2025). La respuesta está en la colaboración: en Accenture, los gerentes reciben alertas de IA cuando un algoritmo sugiere una acción riesgosa (ej.: despedir a alguien con alto potencial). “La tecnología propone, el humano dispone”, resume Marcos Silva, líder de ética digital de la firma.

name: AXA
title: Insurers face a raft of economic challenges - Bangkok Post
description:
Unfavourable economic conditions, political instability, soaring medical costs and natural disaster risks are the top challenges facing insurance companies in Thailand, while the country's ageing society could support continued health insurance expansion.
Guillaume Mirabaud, chief executive of AXA Insurance Thailand, said there are several challenges for 2026, with the top concern the economic context.
"This is a strong reminder that Thai society needs to prepare for more extreme events, as climate change is not theoretical," said Mr Mirabaud.
"Individuals and small business owners should be aware they will need better coverage," said Mr Mirabaud.
On health insurance, the key challenge will be to keep medical costs under control, so that more people can access private insurance and be better protected.
text:
Unfavourable economic conditions, political instability, soaring medical costs and natural disaster risks are the top challenges facing insurance companies in Thailand, while the country's ageing society could support continued health insurance expansion.

Guillaume Mirabaud, chief executive of AXA Insurance Thailand, said there are several challenges for 2026, with the top concern the economic context.

"Global macro uncertainty is unfavourable for business development. Further stabilisation may help a return to a more favourable trend," he said.

"Political instability in the country is another negative factor, as investors and companies lack predictability."

In terms of insurance, he said the key risk is natural catastrophes following the earthquake in March and several floods, including the recent inundation in the southern provinces.

"This is a strong reminder that Thai society needs to prepare for more extreme events, as climate change is not theoretical," said Mr Mirabaud.

Insurance companies should revise their underwriting as prices will "inevitably increase", he said.

"Individuals and small business owners should be aware they will need better coverage," said Mr Mirabaud.

On the regulatory front, he said insurers are expected to be improved, with Thai risk monitoring and good insurance practices catching up with more mature markets.

"This includes setting up ground rules for electric vehicles, which have resulted in heavy losses to date, as well as eventually enforcing a named driver for each motor policy," said Mr Mirabaud.

On health insurance, the key challenge will be to keep medical costs under control, so that more people can access private insurance and be better protected. "This requires a strong political will to contain medical expenses and a deal between medical providers and insurance sectors under the monitoring of regulator and government," Mr Mirabaud stressed.

Besides macroeconomic and political instability, the low-interest rate environment is another major headwind that insurers are encountering, says the Thai unit of German insurer Allianz.

The Bank of Thailand's Monetary Policy Committee, at its final meeting of 2025, lowered the policy interest rate by 25 basis points to 1.25% to help an economy beset by multiple challenges including political uncertainty, a strengthening baht, and US tariffs.

The central bank also said it would continue to ease monetary policy to support economic growth

Thomas Wilson, country manager, president and chief executive of Allianz Ayudhya Assurance, said low interest rates do not help attract investments to unit-linked products, a type of life insurance policy that combines life insurance protection with investment opportunities through unit-linked funds.

"I think consumer confidence and their willingness to commit to long-term savings and long-term health premiums is decreasing," he said.

Meanwhile, Thailand is approaching a demographic milestone, with 21.3% of the population over 60 in 2025. The figure is projected to rise to 25% in 2030 and nearly 30% by 2040.

"Thailand has one of the oldest demographics in the world, with the trend likely to accelerate," said Mr Wilson.

Coupled with demographics, the increase of emerging diseases is among the factors driving health insurance premiums, which are expected to expand by nearly 10% in both 2025 and this year, according to Piyapadh Vana-Ukrit, chairman of the accident and health insurance committee at the Thai General Insurance Association.

name: Levi Strauss
title: In 2006, two years before the global financial crisis. There were also people in Korea who noticed t..
description:
In 2006, two years before the global financial crisis.
There were also people in Korea who noticed the risk of subprime mortgage insolvency like Michael Burry.
At the time, the man offered his company to bet on the crisis by paying 10 billion won in insurance premiums every year.
The insurance money he received from the insurance company after a period of labor was about 200 billion won, 7.4 times the principal amount.
After signing up for an insurance product, housing prices rose, leading to criticism of my decision to sign up for the product.
text:
In 2006, two years before the global financial crisis. There were also people in Korea who noticed the risk of subprime mortgage insolvency like Michael Burry. At the time, the man offered his company to bet on the crisis by paying 10 billion won in insurance premiums every year. But the market has gone against this man's idea for two years. Everyone was drunk on optimism. He had to endure criticism and ridicule for wasting money in the company. The insurance money he received from the insurance company after a period of labor was about 200 billion won, 7.4 times the principal amount. His counterpart was investment genius Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway.

The main character of this episode is "Mer," the No. 1 Naver blog economy that attracts 300,000 people to his blog every day in an era that marks the end of text. A former member of Samsung`s open recruitment company, he has worked at six financial institutions to develop financial products and review credit investment, and plans to post something on the treadmill at 6 a.m. every morning. The book he mentioned on his blog jumps 100 spots in sales in a day, and the industry he covered in his article becomes the biggest concern for investors.

To make money from investment, you shouldn't move the same way as others. You must understand the flow of the world and prepare for the future to come. This is why the "power to read 1%" is important in the flood of information. Kim Yu-shin's 'Deep Money Talk' introduces his world reading and investment philosophy through a written interview with 'Mer'.

How to choose and write blog content...

Q. How did you first write on your blog.

A. I started writing on my blog in earnest because I needed to organize my thoughts. I think if your thoughts stay in your head, you will have more gaps. In the process of organizing thoughts in writing, I started a blog with a light heart to fill in the gaps.

Q. Could you briefly introduce your career.

A. After joining Samsung through open recruitment, he has worked at six financial companies including GE. Financial companies have accumulated expertise in the field of financial product development. Financial product development is called the flower of financial companies. This is because proper financial product development is possible only when the entire area such as sales, marketing, risk management, and profitability is understood to the bottom.

Recently, he is in charge of reviewing and approving large loan investments. Wide knowledge and trained judgment skills are required because various investments must be handled, not just loans. The process of writing is the process of making acquired data and information mine. It is a great help to broaden your knowledge and improve your judgment skills.

Q. If there are any criteria for selecting a blog post.

A. I start working out at 6 a.m. They walk on the treadmill for about an hour and allocate the priorities of what to do that day. After that, blog posts are also selected while learning. The criteria for selecting a topic is 'what I'm curious about as of today'. When you find out what you are curious about and organize it, the writing is born.

Q. The scope of the writing is wide but the depth is considerable, but how do you collect information.

A. I think it's a combination of books, searches, and internal reports. I visit the library near my house on weekends. I borrow 14 books from the library on average a month. I get the most information from the book, but there are also disadvantages to the information I get from the book. Since time spent writing, editing, and publishing books is included, recent information is often missing. This part is supplemented with a search.

Mer's investment secret

Q. If you have your own investment philosophy.

A. Aim to produce a robust profit with a good balance of risk and return. This is why they prefer to organize and operate their portfolios rather than individual stocks.

Q. What is the way to balance risk and profit.

A. In practice, the '+5% & -2%' rule is used a lot. It's a personal theory, not an academic theory.

When dealing with a lot of investments, I learned from my experience that removing the risk of about 2% will balance the return and risk even if I allow a close 5% more.

If risk and additional revenue are presented as a kind of set product, they have a lot of experience that negotiations have proceeded smoothly while balancing risk and return.

Q. What was your most successful investment experience.

A. I would like to point out my experience of overcoming the 2008 financial crisis through insurance hedging.

In 2006, two years before the financial crisis, I visited a subprime mortgage company and heard the product description, and I was convinced that there was a problem with the market. So, I pushed for insurance products to hedge risks. There were also loud voices of opposition within the company because it had to pay 10 billion won a year only in insurance premiums. After signing up for an insurance product, housing prices rose, leading to criticism of my decision to sign up for the product.

At that time, the product was heard through Berkshire Hathaway, owned by Warren Buffett. When the financial crisis came, the insurance products that were subscribed were powerful, and eventually, they were able to receive insurance payments up to 7.4 times the premiums paid at the time. About 200 billion won was received from Berkshire Hathaway.

Q. What investment did you lose the most.

A. There is no big loss of investment. This is because losses are only allowed up to 0.2% on investments. In other words, if the investment of 1 trillion won is approved, the amount of damage allowed is 2 billion won. There is no experience of failure to invest in individual approval cases, but if the unapproved case goes well, it will be regrettable.

Asset Market Outlook for 2026

Q. Last year, artificial intelligence (AI)-related stocks rose significantly. Will this trend continue this year.

A. I think next year's AI will be a winner-take-all trend. Only one or two leading companies survive, and I think we will see the process of losing companies losing huge investments and being kicked out of the market within two to three years.

Those who made money in the gold rush to find gold mines in the western United States were not gold seekers. Levi Strauss, who made jeans for miners' work clothes, or Bamuel Brannon, who became California's first millionaire by selling food and tools to miners, made money. James Marshall, who discovered gold in Coloma, was poor in his later years, and John Southerner found gold in his land, but lost his property due to manpower outflows and looting.

Q. Are there any new industries that will emerge in terms of investment.

A. Companies that supply parts and services to AI companies seem to be more accessible than AI companies. Personally, I am also interested in space data centers.

Q. If you are looking at the domestic real estate market.

A. The big trend is polarization. Seoul, the metropolitan area, and key provincial areas with jobs will continue to maintain their values, but the rest of the region is not easy.

In terms of regulation, it will be difficult to maintain the land transaction permit system (toilet system) for all areas of Seoul and parts of the metropolitan area until the end of this year. I think we will have no choice but to lift the local tax system and touch the holding tax in key areas where prices are not set.

Jeonse will be quickly replaced by monthly rent, and rising housing costs are likely to be an inevitable trend.

Mer's principle of asset allocation is

Q. If you have your own asset allocation principle.

A. The shares are intended to be distributed within 50%. Looking at the portfolio, it consists of 50% of stocks, 10% of gold and silver, and 40% of cash equivalents (including short-term government bonds).

There were about 20% of U.S. government bonds, but the proportion of cash equivalents increased by organizing them.

Q. Looking at the portfolio we disclosed, it doesn't seem to have a U.S. stock weight.

A. It has been investing long-term in the Korean shipbuilding industry with a Japanese general trading company since 2023. This alone makes it impossible to invest in U.S. stocks because nearly half of the portfolio is full.

Q. Why do you invest in shipbuilding.

A. They prefer industry analysis to individual companies. Although it is currently in a recession, I thought to find an industry that has an opportunity to grow, and the industry that I found was the shipbuilding industry.

Eco-friendly power generation was the trend, but this alone seemed to have limitations in securing the necessary energy. As the proportion of LNG use is expected to increase for a while, Korea naturally drew attention as an LNG ship with strengths.

Q. How did you decide the timing of your investment.

A. The shipbuilding industry thought the timing of the deficit turning into a surplus was the timing of investment. It put about 5% of its weight into shipbuilding-related ETFs in 2023, and expanded its share of investment in 2025 when it is certain to turn into a surplus. It is an ETF investment, but the rate of return is more than three times.

Q. What is your portfolio plan for this year.

A. Do not plan a portfolio on an annual basis. They check that the stocks they are currently investing in stop rising completely and replace them.

I don't have much dissatisfaction with the current portfolio, so I'm going to watch the environment change by dragging it until this year.

Q. Which investors do you respect or want to resemble.

A. It's Warren Buffett. It is a wonder that it is not a frequent sale, but a long-term possession and sufficient profit.

Q. If you have a goal in your life.

A. I don't want to do anything I don't want to do, but I want to live by focusing on what I want to do.

Q. If you have any goals for the new year.

A. I'm planning to write my next book, The Power of Reading 1%.

Q. If you could advise a new person in society who is new to social life regarding his or her work life.

A. There is a famous adage in Yeouido that says, "The number of office workers is their personality." When a number usually called performance comes out, words gain strength and people who mess with it disappear. I think concentrating on my job and producing results is the most important attitude toward working life.

Mer's book, "The Power to Read 1%."

The "power to read 1%" deals with the "technology of insight" that reads the nature and flow of issues in vast amounts of data and complex news. Author Mer emphasizes the importance of 'connection intelligence' that connects fragmented information into one complete context.

In particular, it deals with key global economic issues such as semiconductors, energy, currency, and real estate in various ways and presents practical analysis methods. In other words, it is a book that gives you a glimpse of Mer's secret to looking behind the phenomenon.

Readers of this book will practice asking why it happened and what will come next, not what happened. In other words, it is a book that expands critical thinking and helps investors move preemptively through information acquisition. If there are readers who want to interpret the world from their own perspective and preempt future opportunities, I recommend reading the "power to read 1%."

Mencius said, "Muhansan 恒 without 恒産 ." This means that if the stomach is not filled, it is difficult to practice morality. It is believed that peace is difficult to maintain at home and at the national level if the economy does not stand straight. Through interviews with authors who have written books on investment, finance, and technology, "Deep Money Talk" has been planned and serialized to see the secrets of "恒産."

name: Adobe
title: Happy New Year! No. 1 Story for 2025: Bombshell Overturns Myth of 1 Percent Difference
description:
The new findings reveal that human DNA is far more different from chimp DNA than previously thought.
Many times over the years, I’ve discussed how this 1 percent claim about humans and chimps is likely wrong.
We can add this difference to the “gap difference,” and calculate a 14 percent to 14.9 percent total difference between human and chimp genomes.
This means that the actual difference between human and chimp DNA is 14 times greater than the often-quoted 1 percent statistic.
For the moment, suffice to say that the old 1 percent difference statistic is the latest icon of evolution to fall.
text:
Editor’s note: Welcome to a Science and Culture Today tradition: a countdown of our Top 10 favorite stories of the past year, concluding now on New Year’s Day. This article was originally published on May 20, 2025. Our staff are enjoying the holidays, as we hope that you are, too! Help keep the daily voice of intelligent design going strong. Please give whatever you can to support the Center for Science and Culture now!

How many times have you heard it said that the human and chimpanzee genomes are so similar that they are only “1 percent different” at the level of their DNA? This shows, we were told, not only that humans and chimps share common ancestry, but that humans aren’t all that special, which is a common talking point in science journalism and other public discussions. After all, we’re just slightly modified chimps! This “fact” has been discussed so much that it has become what the late biologist Jonathan Wells famously called an “icon of evolution.”

But now, new data reported in a recently published Nature paper by Yoo et al. has overturned this previous claim. The new findings reveal that human DNA is far more different from chimp DNA than previously thought.

That should be major news in the science world, yet those involved don’t seem interested in highlighting their discovery. More on that later.

Many times over the years, I’ve discussed how this 1 percent claim about humans and chimps is likely wrong. It is also misleading. No matter how similar humans might be to chimps at the genetic level, anyone who has been to the zoo knows already that chimps and humans are vastly different. After all, we’re the ones writing scientific papers about them—not the other way around. So common sense alone dictates that there is something misleading about that number and how it is used. But the new data show that the previous statistic isn’t just misleading. It’s flat-out false.

As I will elaborate in a subsequent article, this team of researchers has published “complete” sequences of ape genomes that were created ‘from scratch’ rather than using the human genome as a template. As a result, for the first time we can attempt a much more accurate assessment of the true degree of difference between the human and chimp genomes.

The results are groundbreaking:

At least 12.5 percent and possibly up to 13.3 percent of the chimp and human genomes represent a “gap difference” between the two genomes. That means there’s a “gap” in one genome compared to the other, often where they are so different, they cannot even be aligned.

There are also significant alignable sections of the two genomes that show “short nucleotide variations” which differ by only about 1.5 percent. We can add this difference to the “gap difference,” and calculate a 14 percent to 14.9 percent total difference between human and chimp genomes. This means that the actual difference between human and chimp DNA is 14 times greater than the often-quoted 1 percent statistic.

It’s true that large portions of the human genome are still only about 1.5 percent genetically different from the chimp genome. We’ll explore what that means in a subsequent post. But the new data reveal just how little this one fact tells us about the overall picture. We now know that major portions of the two genomes — 12.5 percent to 13.3 percent of the human genome, in fact — are so different that arguably the sections are unalignable and/or not directly present in one genome or the other.

Burying the Lede

One very peculiar thing about the research just published is that nowhere in the technical paper is this bombshell discovery clearly reported, and nowhere is it stated clearly that human and chimp DNA is some ~14 percent different. Even an explainer article in Nature — which usually do a great job of translating technical findings for the average scientist — does not mention this huge finding. You have to dig deep into the Supplementary Data to find it, and even there it is opaquely stated in technical jargon.

This data has huge implications for the long-quoted statistic that we are only 1 percent genetically different from chimps, and many people are interested in this question for its implications regarding evolution, origins, and the exceptional status of human beings. Yet the papers almost seemed like they want to obscure the numbers, making them hard to find for the reader, whether a scientist or layman.

How hard would it have been for the original Nature paper or — even better — the explainer article to say that this new data shows that the human and chimp genomes are more like 14 percent to 15 percent different rather than 1 percent?

And yet for some very strange reason they did not do that. In journalism, this is called “burying the lede” — putting the main point of your reporting, the most notable fact, under a heap of less important verbiage. Sometimes this happens due to incompetence. Other times, it is deliberate.

Remembering the Icon

As Jonathan Wells taught us, “icons of evolution” are arguments for evolution that get recycled over and over again — yet are not true. How do we know the 1 percent statistic is such an icon? Science popularizer Bill Nye, “The Science Guy,” provided a great example when he wrote in his 2014 book Undeniable:

As our understanding of DNA has increased, we have come to understand that we share around 98.8 percent of our gene sequence with chimpanzees. This is striking evidence for chimps and chumps to have a common ancestor. P. 248

The Smithsonian Museum of Natural History’s website likewise states:

DNA is thus especially important in the study of evolution. The amount of difference in DNA is a test of the difference between one species and another — and thus how closely or distantly related they are.

While the genetic difference between individual humans today is minuscule – about 0.1%, on average – study of the same aspects of the chimpanzee genome indicates a difference of about 1.2%.

Similar statements are found in the Smithsonian itself — the nation’s museum! — visited by nearly 4 million people yearly. I took this photo in 2023 when I visited:

A caption below declares that: “DNA evidence … confirms … that modern humans and chimpanzees diverged from a common ancestor…”

David Klinghoffer provides a nice rundown of other sources that have cited this statistic:

“We share more than 98 percent of our DNA and almost all of our genes with our closest living relative, the chimpanzee.” (Nature)

“[A]bout 99 percent of our DNA is identical to that of chimpanzees.” (Kevin Williamson, National Review)

“Most studies indicate that when genomic regions are compared between chimpanzees and humans, they share about 98.5 percent sequence identity.” (Scientific American)

“Humans and chimps share a surprising 98.8 percent of their DNA.” (American Museum of Natural History)

“[H]umans share about 99 percent of our DNA with chimpanzees, making them our closest living relatives.” (Science)

“Chimps, Humans 96 Percent the Same, Gene Study Finds.” (National Geographic News)

This “1 percent human-chimp genetic difference” statistic has been widely promoted and is widely believed. It’s undeniably an icon of evolution. But Dr. Wells also noted that these icons are like “zombies” — they don’t die easily. Instead, they keep being repeated, long after they’ve been refuted.

If that’s true, then don’t expect the 1 percent statistic to go away anytime soon. In fact, as I mentioned, the new Nature paper makes it very difficult to dig up the figures I’ve quoted here, so I suspect we’ll continue to see zombie numbers quoted, despite what the newly published data shows. I’ll explain all of that in more detail in a subsequent article. For the moment, suffice to say that the old 1 percent difference statistic is the latest icon of evolution to fall. May it rest in peace.
